snippet: New results from an Oregon study found that Medicaid coverage reduced the rate of depression and made low-income adults more financially secure, if not healthier.
abstract: Oregon Health Study published in The New England Journal of Medicine finds that Medicaid coverage reduces rate of depression but does not make adults healthier, despite more spent on health care and more visits to doctors and hospitals; study compared thousands of low-income people in Oregon who received access to Medicaid with identical population that did not.
lead_paragraph: New results from an Oregon study found that Medicaid coverage reduced the rate of depression and made low-income adults more financially secure, if not healthier.

headline.seo: Study Finds Health Care Use Rises With Expanded Medicaid
headline.main: Medicaid Access Increases Use of Care, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Expanded Medicaid Raises Use of Care

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
